Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Towards Building Time Capsule for Online Social Activities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The capability to preserve, model, and predict information cascades over online social networks has many theoretical and practical implications, e.g., for marketing, recommendation filtering, and studying of societal behavior. Massive empirical data sets on users' online social activities are being collected, but they are often too big to analyze. The goal of this project is to design graph generative models and summarization techniques that can preserve pertinent information about online social interactions that lead to interesting events, e.g., viral diffusion of information or drastic change of user behavior. Towards this end, the project will develop generative models that can capture the dynamic evolution of user activity graphs (UAGs), which represent a sequence of inter-user communications/actions. At the microscopic level, the project will investigate user influence in the recruitment process. In addition, the project will design graph summarization techniques that can achieve good tradeoffs between data compression ratio, computational complexities, and accuracy in answering fundamental queries, such as identifying 'influential' sources of information cascades.

Broader Impact: If successful, this project will provide efficient methods for storing/archiving massive graph data to support longitudinal study on the dynamics of online social interactions, which has potential impact on multiple disciplines (e.g., economics, history, political sciences, and social science). This project will help train future researchers and practitioners in online social networking and network science through classroom curriculum development and online teaching. The PIs will continue ongoing diversity recruitment and outreach to K-12 students. Transfer of technology into commercial practice is made feasible through partnership with industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:  PI Xu and his Ph.D. and M.S. students have worked together with several collaborators on five research problems closely related to this project.  First, they worked with the database group at the East China Normal University (ECNU), a partner institution specified in the proposal, on the analysis of Weibo (the Twitter of China) data with the objective of coming up with models that can help predict early on the set of events that would later become popular or viral.  Borrowing ideas from PI Xu's past works (circa 2009) on modeling the evolution of the popularities of AT&T's IPTV channels over time, they were able to come up with a fairly accurate model of how the popularities of events evolve over time.  Second, they worked with the ECNU team also on measuring the number of violations (i.e., errors) to a functional dependency over distributed databases and data sets.  This problem is closely related to this project, since a large OSN can often be viewed as a distributed database in that its data can be produced, processed, and stored at many different physical sites, and an OSN often would like to ensure a certain level of data consistency across these physical sites.   They proposed a distributed data streaming algorithm that can estimate such quantities much more accurately than all existing approaches, while incurring the same amount of communication cost.  Third, they worked with Shanghai Jiao Tong University (STJU), another partner institution, to investigate the topic of cognitive social networks, focusing on the impact of social relationships among the network users on the packet routing performance in mobile ad-hoc networks.   Fourth, they worked with the UC Davis team and Australian researchers on the problem of accurately measuring the statistics of OSN cascades (each cascade is a causal chain of OSN user activities), which are of considerable interest to advertisers, OSN operators, and application developers.  They proposed a measurement technique that combines graph sampling and streaming to achieve a much better measurement accuracy, given the sample (computer) memory budget, than existing graph sampling based approaches.  Last, they proposed a novel O(1) semi-streaming data structure and algorithm, queue-proportional sampling (QPS), that can sample a packet with a probability proportional to the length of the queue the packet belongs to.  This research effort was motivated by and is closely related to this project, because an OSN provider often needs to sample a user from a subpopulation (analogous to a queue above) with a probability proportional to an aggregate statistic of the subpopulation (analogous to the length of the queue above), and this sampling operation often needs to be done very quickly (say in microseconds).  They have also applied this QPS approach to the classical networking problem of crossbar scheduling in input-queued switches.  More specifically, they used QPS to augment two excellent crossbar scheduling algorithms: iSLIP and Serena.  Both QPS-augmented algorithms, namely QPS-iSLIP and QPS-Serena, are shown to outperform the original algorithms, in both throughput and delay, under various load conditions and traffic patterns, by a wide margin.  


Broader Impact:  The measurement-based characterization results from this project have improved our understanding of the information diffusion process (e.g., how ideas spread, how new applications get adopted) over online social media, which relies heavily on user-based invitations/recruitments. Their micro-level analysis of how user influence one another and the roles played by users can help predict future user behavior. This has led to better forecasting of information cascades, which have implications on resource provisioning of networks/data centers as well as marketing strategies. Coupled with their exploration of graph summarization/streaming, it has led to better and more efficient ways of collecting/storing user activity data.  From summer 2014 to summer 2015, PI Xu and Professor Bill Lin (UCSD) had taken on the important and heavy task of co-organizing ACM Sigmetrics 2015, in conjunction with ACM Federated Computing Research Conference (FCRC).  ACM Sigmetrics 2015 was a great success in almost every aspect.  The Sigmetrics conference is closely related to this project, as recent Sigmetrics conferences all had several papers in their respective programs dealing with OSN issues.  In fact, such community service efforts were planned in the educational and broader impact section of the proposal.   PI Xu funded and supervised a female M.S. student to working on the fourth research problem described above (of measuring the sizes of cascades in an OSN).  This research effort has resulted in a paper in a reputed networking conference (IEEE ICCCN 2017).  This research experience helped her land a summer internship at and later a full-time position from Facebook.  The three Ph.D. students who worked on this project have all made significant progresses towards their degrees.
